description: Middle English, from Old French tabour, ultimately from Arabic طُنْبُور‎ (ṭunbūr).

entries.meaning: In traditional music, a small drum played with a single stick, leaving the player's other hand free to play a melody on a three-holed pipe.

verbs.description: tabor (third-person singular simple present tabors, present participle taboring, simple past and past participle tabored)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (a sound) with a tabor.

description: From various Slavic languages, from a Turkic language. Compare Ottoman Turkish طابور‎ (tabur).

entries.meaning: A military train of men and wagons; an encampment of such resources.
examples: A Polish-Lithuanian tabor besieged by twenty or thirty thousand Tartars must have closely resembled the overland wagon trains of American pioneers attacked by the Sioux or the Cherokee.
